author: Morgan Housel
summary: A small number of events account for the majority of outcomes. Walt Disney produced 400+ cartoons that mostly lost money, but Snow White changed everything. Venture capital data shows 65% of investments lose money, but 1% make 20x+ returns.
key_takeaways: Long tails (outlier events) have tremendous influence in finance.
You can be wrong most of the time and still end up spectacularly right.
It's normal for a lot of things to fail - don't overreact when they do.

questions.question: What percentage of venture capital investments typically lose money?
questions.explanation: Out of more than 21,000 venture financings from 2004 to 2014, 65% lost money. Yet the 1% that made 20x+ returns drive the overall success of venture capital.

questions.question: How did great art dealers like Heinz Berggruen build valuable collections?

options.text: By carefully selecting only guaranteed masterpieces
By buying vast quantities and waiting for a few winners to emerge
By having insider knowledge about which artists would become famous
By investing only in already-famous artists

questions.explanation: Great art dealers operated like index funds - they bought everything they could in portfolios, then waited for a few winners to emerge. Perhaps 99% was of little value, but the 1% that was Picasso made up for everything.

questions.question: What lesson does Walt Disney's career teach about success in business?

options.text: Every project should be carefully planned to guarantee success
A single tail event (like Snow White) can make up for hundreds of failures
Failure should be avoided at all costs in creative industries
Animation is the only reliable path to wealth

questions.explanation: Disney produced 400+ cartoons, most of which lost money. But the 83 minutes of Snow White were all that mattered - it paid off all debts and transformed the company. Huge success is often the result of a single tail event.
